name: Peter Neronha
tweet: A tradition that happens rain or shine - happy Providence #StPatricksDay parade!  https://t.co/yz0LvJGhFt

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips   https://t.co/zWD72ELrxT offers resources to help w/compliance & understanding of APRA & OMA, including APRA checklist & entering executive session OMA example. Many of our open gov. findings can be searched through @clerkbase ⬇️ #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips  If a public body denies your records request you can:  1⃣ appeal to the Chief Administrative Officer of the public body  2⃣ file a complaint with the Attorney General  or 3⃣ file a lawsuit in Superior Court.  #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: A rolling quorum can potentially be created through a series of separate conversations, emails, or even social media posts if the separate communications constitute a collective discussion among a quorum. (3/3) #OpenGovTips #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: Anytime members of a public body converse outside of a properly noticed meeting, they should be extremely careful to avoid creating a situation where a quorum discusses matters within the purview of the public body. (2/3) #OpenGovTips #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips  Whenever a quorum (simple majority unless otherwise defined) of a public body convenes to discuss/act upon matters over which the public body has supervision, control, jurisdiction, or advisory power, the requirements of the OMA must be met. (1/3) #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: Before withholding an entire record, a body must consider whether it's possible to produce the record(s) in part or w/redactions. If possible to produce a record w/reasonable redactions rather than withholding altogether, then the body must do so. (2/2) #OpenGovTips #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips  Whenever a public body withholds entire records in response to an APRA request, a body must state that no reasonably segregable portion of the records can be provided. (1/2) #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: Each year, we host a free Open Government Summit, where RI'ers can learn about public records & open meetings laws.  Save the date for this year's VIRTUAL summit on 6/3 in partnership w/@RWULaw Alumni Association & @ClerkBase  Watch our 2021 summit ⬇️ #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: Under OMA (w/o EO in effect) members of a public body must meet in person unless 1 of 2 exceptions in statute (service in military or disability) applies. The body may also provide virtual means for the public to observe/participate in meetings. (4/4) #SunshineWeek #OpenGovTips

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: If a public body conducts a virtual or hybrid meeting, the public must be provided access to the meeting through adequate alternative means. Executive Order 22-20 runs until March 31, 2022 unless renewed or modified. (3/4) #OpenGovTips #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: Under Executive Order 22-20, public bodies may choose to meet in person as provided for in the OMA but may also choose to meet by virtual means or to have a hybrid meeting where some participants attend in-person and others attend remotely. (2/4) #OpenGovTips #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips  Executive Order 22-20 modifies certain provisions of the OMA.  Access our guidance on Executive Order 22-20 ⬇️ + read thread for more... (1/4) #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips  Public bodies may request prepayment for certain costs & for search/retrieval after expending 1 free hour. Bodies should consider basis for prepayment estimate & be prepared to explain. Estimates may not be exact but should be thoughtful & reasonable. #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips  In 2021, our office received 93 OMA complaints and 92 APRA complaints – both are 7-year highs.  Our Open Gov. team is a great resource for RI'ers w/questions about public records & open meetings (401) 274-4400/riag.ri.gov #SunshineWeek  https://t.co/6ClgmB8wc1

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: #OpenGovTips  In RI, the Access to Public Records Act (APRA) & Open Meetings Act (OMA) are 2 laws crucial to safeguarding the public’s right to be informed about gov. Our Open Gov. team is a great resource for RI'ers w/questions about public records & open meetings. #SunshineWeek

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: It's National #SunshineWeek - an annual recognition of the importance of open & transparent govt. Stay tuned to our twitter feed this week as we promote awareness & understanding of our work & the laws that ensure RI'ers have access to public information. #OpenGovTips

name: Peter Neronha
tweet: Happy #StPatricksDay from a festive  & rainy Newport parade.  https://t.co/VVKDNQ1cGK
